revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} The '''2007–08 Cork players' strike''' was a dispute in Republic of Ireland between the [[Cork GAA|Cork]] [[GAA county|County Board]] and its [[Gaelic football]]ers and [[Hurling|hurlers]]. It led to the footballers and hurlers refusing to play for the Cork County Board. The cause of the strike was the issue of deciding who should pick the [[List of Gaelic games terminology#S|senior]] teams' [[List of Gaelic games terminology#S|selectors]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/sport/gaelic-football/cork-players-go-on-strike-over-selection-row-1243627.html |accessdate=8 February 2008|title=Cork players go on strike over selection row | work=Irish Independent|date=10 December 2007}}</ref> The players believed the [[Manager (Gaelic games)|manager]] should pick the selectors. However, the county board picked the selectors. With the appointment of [[Teddy Holland]] as manager, the players also refused to play under his tutorship since he accepted the job during their time of strike.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/teddy-holland-in-profile-1274660.html|title=Teddy Holland in profile|accessdate=8 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=26 January 2008}}</ref>
The strike drew comment from the [[Taoiseach]], [[Bertie Ahern]],<ref name="irishexaminer.com">{{cite web|title=Ahern: both sides need to keep heads|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/text/story.asp?j=cwojaueygbojeyau&p=z5x47xxx&n=25047076|accessdate=8 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and was the first time in the [[history of the Gaelic Athletic Association]] that a strike caused [[GAA county|inter county]] fixtures not to be played.<ref name="Holland sacked by Cork officials">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0218/hollandt.html|title=Holland sacked by Cork officials|accessdate=18 February 2008 | work=RTÉ News|date=18 February 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080219220328/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0218/hollandt.html| archivedate= 19 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
The strike was the second strike by Cork players in five years. It began on 10 December 2007<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1210/cork.html |title=Cork in crisis |accessdate=18 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=10 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219091406/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1210/cork.html |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and ended on 18 February 2008<ref name="Holland sacked by Cork officials" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2008/0218/1203093495987.html|title=Holland sacked by county board|accessdate=18 February 2008}}</ref> – 97 days after the first threat of strike action<ref name="Strike action threatened in Cork">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1113/cork.html |title=Strike action threatened in Cork |accessdate=18 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=13 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229110717/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1113/cork.html |archivedate=29 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> – and was declared over on 15 February 2008.<ref name="Holland and Cork selectors resign">{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/mheysnauojkf/|title=Holland and Cork selectors resign|accessdate=15 February 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080220060829/http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/mheysnauojkf/| archivedate= 20 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> However Holland was not fired until 18 February.<ref name="Holland still in very hot seat">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=89622|title=Holland still in (very) hot seat|accessdate=17 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article831795.ece|title=Cork's panel closer to a strike|accessdate=5 February 2008 | location=London | work=The Times | date=17 November 2002 | first1=Richard | last1=Ford | first2=Philippe | last2=Naughton}}</ref> Kieran Mulvey, chairman of the Labour Relations Commission, acted as arbitrator between the players and county board.
==Strike build-up== * '''16 October:''' Cork clubs vote to change how selectors are picked. This is confirmed by a second vote on 20 October.<ref name="CORK STRIKE TIMELINE">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/cork-strike-timeline-1275239.html|title=CORK STRIKE TIMELINE|accessdate=12 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=27 January 2008}}</ref> * '''8 November:''' [[Billy Morgan (Gaelic footballer)|Billy Morgan]] resigns as manager because he is no longer allowed to choose selectors for his team.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2007/1108/1194222937420.html|title=Morgan says no to Cork return|accessdate=10 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref> * '''13 November:''' The players issue their first threat of strike action<ref name="Strike action threatened in Cork" /> and are supported in doing so by the [[Gaelic Players Association]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2007/1113/1194550269007.html|title=GPA backs proposed Cork strike|accessdate=10 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref> * '''16 November:''' The players write to their clubs highlighting their objections to the board's decision and state that they are seeking to resolve the issue of appointing a new manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=101703030&p=yxy7x333z&t=gaa|title=Players give the write direction|accessdate=10 February 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080219110617/http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=101703030&p=yxy7x333z&t=gaa |archivedate = 19 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> * '''21 November:''' [[Teddy Holland]] is appointed as team manager along with selectors [[Teddy McCarthy]], Liam Hodnett, Diarmuid O'Donovan and Mick O'Loughlin.<ref name="Holland sacked by county board">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/0219/breaking8.htm|title=Holland sacked by county board|accessdate=19 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times|date=2 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/sport/gaelic-football/teddy-holland-appointed-as-new-cork-manager-1225974.html|title=Teddy Holland appointed as new Cork manager|accessdate=10 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=21 November 2007}}</ref> * '''23 November:''' The footballers meet with Holland to inform him that their dispute is with the means of choosing selectors and not with his appointment.<ref name="CORK STRIKE TIMELINE"/><ref name="rte.ie">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1124/cork.html?rss |title=Cork squads to meet in selector dispute |accessdate=10 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=24 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219143422/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1124/cork.html?rss |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * '''24 November:''' The football and hurling [[List of Gaelic games terminology#P|panels]] plan to discuss the appointment of Teddy Holland and to threaten possible strike action.<ref name="rte.ie"/> * '''3 December:''' Cork players' spokesman, [[Donal Óg Cusack]], gives notice of the players intention to strike.<ref>{{cite web| title=Cusack warns Cork players will walk away| url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=86518|accessdate=8 February 2008}}</ref> * '''9 December:''' Former Cork hurling captain, [[Mark Landers]], requests that the [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] intervene to help resolve the dispute but the GAA declare their neutrality.<ref name="CORK STRIKE TIMELINE"/> * '''12 December:''' The footballers take a team holiday (largely paid for and organised by themselves).<ref name="CORK STRIKE TIMELINE"/>
==Events of the strike== On 10 December, the players officially went on strike.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/sport/gaelic-football/cork-players-go-on-strike-over-selection-row-1243627.html|accessdate=8 February 2008|title=Cork players go on strike over selection row | work=Irish Independent|date=10 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/gaelic_games/7137075.stm|title=Cork senior squads go on strike|accessdate=21 February 2008 | work=BBC News | date=10 December 2007}}</ref> The county board and the players held the first of a series of meetings to try resolve the strike ten days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1220/cork.html |title=No resolution in Cork players' strike |accessdate=10 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=20 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080130040856/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2007/1220/cork.html |archivedate=30 January 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> On 9 January, the hurlers confirmed they would not play in the [[Waterford Crystal Cup]] and the county was forced to give a [[walkover]] to [[Limerick Institute of Technology|Limerick IT]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0109/cork.html |title=Cork players refusing to play |accessdate=8 January 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=9 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112034435/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0109/cork.html |archivedate=12 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Later in the month (23 January), Teddy Holland issued a press statement announcing he would not resign.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/mheyojgbqlql/rss2/|title=Resignation not an option for Cork football manager|accessdate=8 February 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080220130007/http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/mheyojgbqlql/rss2/| archivedate= 20 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> More than 100 club delegates voted unanimously in support of Holland at a county board meeting held on 30 January.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=244705954&p=z447x666x&t=gaa|title=Cork County Board firmly behind Holland|accessdate=10 February 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080219110622/http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=244705954&p=z447x666x&t=gaa |archivedate = 19 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Three days earlier (27 January), in a bid to resolve their issues, the players and the county board had held 18 hours of talks, chaired by Kieran Mulvey, which ended in stalemate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0127/cork.html |title=No resolution in Cork players' strike |accessdate=10 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=27 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080130125841/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0127/cork.html |archivedate=30 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Mulvey had been asked to chair the talks by [[Nickey Brennan]], the [[Presidents of the Gaelic Athletic Association|President of the Gaelic Athletic Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/01/31/GAA-Cork-strike-feature/|title=Cork players deserve our support|accessdate=10 February 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080403005505/http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/01/31/GAA-Cork-strike-feature/ |archivedate = 3 April 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
In the week leading up to the [[National Football League (Ireland)|National Football League]] game against [[Meath GAA|Meath]], the Cork county board were unable to guarantee a team would be available to play the game. Consequently, on 30 January the game was postponed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/sport/gaelic-football/gaa-confirm-that-meath-v-cork-wont-happen-on-saturday-1277737.html|title=GAA confirm that Meath v Cork won't happen on Saturday|accessdate=8 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=30 January 2008}}</ref> The [[Taoiseach]], [[Bertie Ahern]], called on both sides to resolve the dispute<ref name="irishexaminer.com" /> on 5 February and further talks between Kieran Mulvey and [[Paraic Duffy]], the Director General of the GAA, were held.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/gaa/article3405803.ece|archive-url=https://archive.is/20080219153148/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/gaa/article3405803.ece|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 February 2008|title=Duffy bids to broker peace in Cork|accessdate=7 February 2008}}</ref>
On 7 February the players refused a solution offered by the county board and it looked likely that Cork would be removed from both the [[National Hurling League]] and National Football League<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/cork-players-say-no-1283545.html|title=Cork players say no|accessdate=8 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|first=Martin|last=Breheny|date=7 February 2008}}</ref> and be [[relegated]] for the following season. It was claimed that under GAA rules that if a team was unable to take part in two league games that they should be disqualified from the league.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/cork-can-go-to-hell-1285855.html|title=Cork can go to hell|accessdate=22 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=9 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/cork-descend-into-civil-war-1280211.html|title=Cork descend into civil war|accessdate=22 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=3 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0208/cork.html |title=Cork players furious at 'spin' |accessdate=22 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=8 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211125445/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0208/cork.html |archivedate=11 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A second football match was to be played on 16 February<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/page/allianz_nfl_2008_fixtures.html |title=Allianz National Football League 2008 |accessdate=10 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207172145/http://www.gaa.ie/page/allianz_nfl_2008_fixtures.html |archivedate=7 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> while the second hurling game was due on 17 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/page/allianz_nhl_2008_fixtures.html |title=Allianz Hurling League 2008 |accessdate=10 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129202318/http://www.gaa.ie/page/allianz_nhl_2008_fixtures.html |archivedate=29 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On 8 February, the Cork players reacted negatively to what they thought was an attempt by the county board to split the footballers and hurlers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=245654112&p=z456548y8&t=gaa|title=Cork 'furious' at attempt to 'split players'|accessdate=10 February 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080219110628/http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=245654112&p=z456548y8&t=gaa |archivedate = 19 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> when a press release claimed the players would accept Holland as manager.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2008/0207/1201903706561.html|title=Cork release details of rejected document|accessdate=10 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref> The following day [[Roy Keane]] compared the 2002 strike to the [[2002 Roy Keane Saipan incident|Saipan incident]] and warned about players becoming too powerful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/irishexaminer/pages/story.aspx-qqqg=sport-qqqm=sport-qqqa=sport-qqqid=54862-qqqx=1.asp |title=Keane: 2002 strike was Cork GAA’s Saipan |accessdate=9 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080212083907/http://www.irishexaminer.com/irishexaminer/pages/story.aspx-qqqg=sport-qqqm=sport-qqqa=sport-qqqid=54862-qqqx=1.asp |archivedate=12 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> A poll showed that 56 percent of fans supported the strike and 70 percent believed the actions of the board damaged Cork's chance of winning [[All-Ireland championships (disambiguation)|All-Ireland championships]] that year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0209/cork.html |title=Poll shows support for Cork players |accessdate=12 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=9 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212193622/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0209/cork.html |archivedate=12 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The Cork county board, on 12 February, voted 96–13 in favour of entering binding arbitration with the players in a bid to save the teams being disqualified from the leagues<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0212/cork.html |accessdate=13 February 2008 |title=Cork board agree to arbitration (RTÉ) |work=RTÉ News |date=12 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213163020/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0212/cork.html |archivedate=13 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/12/GAA-Cork-story/?facets/sport-space/ireland-locale/ |title=Cork county board agrees to arbitration (Setanta) |accessdate=13 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219102240/http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/12/GAA-Cork-story/?facets%2Fsport-space%2Fireland-locale%2F |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and Nickey Brennan called for the dispute to end, "however it is achieved."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5i1vF0YhF4TOgyDEwVOVV7cDFXFRQ|title=Brennan calls for Cork resolution|accessdate=10 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> On 14 February, the players met with Mulvey and agreed to accept the [[arbitration]] in an attempt to end the strike, then in its 95th day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.ie/irishexaminer/pages/story.aspx-qqqg=sport-qqqm=sport-qqqa=sport-qqqid=55349-qqqx=1.asp |title=Arbitration deal brings GAA strike to an end |accessdate=15 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080218114011/http://www.examiner.ie/irishexaminer/pages/story.aspx-qqqg=sport-qqqm=sport-qqqa=sport-qqqid=55349-qqqx=1.asp |archivedate=18 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Outcome of the arbitration=== The outcome of arbitration on 15 February was as follows:
* Teddy Holland and his selectors were to resign from their positions. * The Cork players committed not to engage in future strikes. * A new management committee would be made up of five county board members and two players.<ref name="Holland and Cork selectors resign"/> * The new management would be able to pick their own [[List of Gaelic games terminology#S|selectors]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setantasports.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/20/GAA-Counihan-set-to-name-selectors/?facets/sport-space/great-britain-locale/gaa/ |title=Counihan names Rebel selectors |accessdate=22 February 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
===Last days of the strike=== Many newspapers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/gaa/article3436799.ece|archive-url=https://archive.is/20080217231133/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/gaa/article3436799.ece|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 February 2008|title=Peace breaks out in Cork at last|accessdate=17 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=89599|title=BREAKING NEWS: Holland gone as strike ends|accessdate=17 February 2008}}</ref><ref name="Holland to go as peace breaks out">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2008/0215/1202938442481.html?via=mr|title=Holland to go as peace breaks out|accessdate=17 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref> declared the strike over on 15 February after the players accepted the outcome of the arbitration and also declared that Teddy Holland had resigned. However, the GAA confirmed that the Cork-versus-[[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] football and Cork-versus-[[Waterford GAA|Waterford]] hurling games that were due to take place were to be called off.<ref name="Holland to go as peace breaks out" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hill16.ie/viewstoryhill16.asp?mainheading=Word+on+The+Hill&id=9549&viewstory=yes |title=Dubs v Cork NFL clash off |accessdate=27 February 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
The county board called an emergency meeting to discuss the recommendations of the arbitration and especially the recommendation from Mulvey that Holland should resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/15/GAA-Cork-county-board-meeting/?facets/sport-space/ireland-locale/gaa/ |title=Cork board call emergency meeting |accessdate=16 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219102252/http://sports.setanta.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/15/GAA-Cork-county-board-meeting/?facets%2Fsport-space%2Fireland-locale%2Fgaa%2F |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> By 16 February, uncertainty had emerged over the status of the strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishnews.com/appnews/2008/2/597/5776/580340_336794514601Hollandre.html |title=Holland resignation will end Cork strike |accessdate=17 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123031334/http://www.irishnews.com/appnews/2008/2/597/5776/580340_336794514601Hollandre.html |archivedate=23 January 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0216/cork.html |title=Cork board holding emergency meeting |accessdate=16 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=16 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219154858/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0216/cork.html |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> While the county board and Holland met to discuss the issues,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0217/cork.html |title=Cork Co Board to meet again |accessdate=17 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=17 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218054837/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0217/cork.html |archivedate=18 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> an expected vote by the county board to remove Holland was never called.<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/sport/hurling/article3440178.ece|title=Cork Co Board to meet Holland today as row drags on|accessdate=17 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Holland meanwhile issued a statement that didn't indicate if he had stepped down and stated that he was neutral saying: ''I am my own man and I am proud to be a Cork football man.'' Holland said the claim that six people had refused the job before him was false and there was no threat of strike when he took the job.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=246485780&p=z46486486&t=gaa|title=Holland issues statement|accessdate=16 February 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080219110633/http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=246485780&p=z46486486&t=gaa |archivedate = 19 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> However, a statement in support of the strike had been issued by the Gaelic Players Association on 13 November 2007, a week before Holland took the job.
On 17 February it was clear Holland had not resigned or been fired by the county board and that the strike continued.<ref name="Holland still in very hot seat"/><ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk" /> The county board issued a statement saying that they would meet on Monday 18 February to end the strike.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0217/cork1.html |title=Cork dispute nearing resolution |accessdate=17 February 2008 |work=RTÉ News |date=17 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219154903/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0217/cork1.html |archivedate=19 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The strike officially ended on 18 February – 97 days after the first threat of strike –<ref name="Strike action threatened in Cork" /> when, as expected,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=89706| title=Holland to be voted out tonight|accessdate=18 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/gaelic_games/7250242.stm|title=End in sight to Cork GAA crisis |accessdate=18 February 2008 | work=BBC News | date=18 February 2008}}</ref> the county board voted 89–19 to fire Teddy Holland and his selectors, who refused to step down.<ref name="Holland sacked by Cork officials" /><ref name="Holland sacked by county board" />
==Aftermath of the strike== The seven-man panel appointed to help find the next manager began its search as soon as Holland had been removed, and included players [[Nicholas Murphy]] and [[Derek Kavanagh]].<ref name="Holland sacked by Cork officials" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5goCp_30myaGotvxxRdHjkcE2yFeA|title=Cork appoint player representatives|accessdate=18 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> [[Conor Counihan]] was appointed Cork's new football [[Manager (Gaelic games)|manager]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setantasports.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/19/GAA-New-Cork-boss/|title=Counihan named new Cork boss|accessdate=18 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> with the right to name his own selectors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setantasports.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/20/GAA-Counihan-set-to-name-selectors/?facets/sport-space/great-britain-locale/gaa/|title=Counihan names Rebel selectors|accessdate=22 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> On 20 February, [[Seán Óg Ó hAilpín]] said that, had the strike carried on beyond 18 February, he and others would have resigned from inter-county hurling and football.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setantasports.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/20/GAA-Sean-Og-on-Cork-dispute/?facets/sport-space/great-britain-locale/gaa/|title=Ó Hailpín: My career was nearly over|accessdate=21 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Cork [[List of Gaelic games terminology#U|Under 21]] footballer, [[Sean Cahalane]], claimed that the Under 21 panel would not have played in place of the seniors if they had been asked by the county board.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/u21s-wouldnt-have-filled-in-1294736.html|title=U-21s 'wouldn't have filled in'|accessdate=22 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|first=Donnchadh|last=Boyle|date=21 February 2008}}</ref>
On 19 February, the [[List of Gaelic games terminology#C|Central Competitions Control Committee]] (CCCC) decided not to remove Cork from the football and hurling leagues, but instead awarded the points from the missed games to their opponents and fined the county board €400 for each game missed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setantasports.com/en/Sport/News/Other-sports/2008/02/19/GAA-Cork-points-forfeited/?facets/sport-space/great-britain-locale/|title=CCCC gives Cork points to opponents|accessdate=19 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] county board offered to play their hurling match with Cork and the Cork county board requested CCCC approve the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=89815|title=Cork request green light|accessdate=20 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/sport/story.asp?j=246869138&p=z46869844|title=Kilkenny offer Cork second chance in NHL clash|accessdate=20 February 2008}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2008/0221/1203471529359.html|title=Kilkenny gesture to Cork rejected|accessdate=21 February 2008 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref> However the CCCC had already awarded Kilkenny the point and would not allow the game to take place. It emerged that Cork couldn't have been removed from the leagues as there was no such rule.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/weighing-up-the-options-for-the--rebel-cause-1294739.html|title= Weighing up the options for the Rebel cause|accessdate=22 February 2008 | work=Irish Independent|date=21 February 2008}}</ref>
Cork went on to win their first football and hurling matches after the strike, beating Dublin's hurlers 2–16 to 3–18<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0309/dublin_cork.html|title=Dublin 2–16 Cork 3–18|accessdate=16 March 2008 | work=RTÉ News|date=9 March 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080313021623/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0309/dublin_cork.html| archivedate= 13 March 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hill16.ie/viewstoryhill16.asp?mainheading=Word+on+The+Hill&id=9693&viewstory=yes |title=Cork finish with flourish to deflate Dubs |accessdate=16 March 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and [[Roscommon GAA|Roscommon]]'s footballers 0–15 to 1–14<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/gaa_results_footballleague.html|accessdate=6 March 2008|title=Allianz National Football League | work=RTÉ News| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080219063226/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/gaa_results_footballleague.html| archivedate= 19 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> However, the decision to award the teams that Cork did not play victory points had a knock-on effect for other teams in both leagues. [[Roscommon GAA|Roscommon]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0316/cork.html|title=Roscommon reopen Cork player strike row|accessdate=16 March 2008 | work=RTÉ News|date=16 March 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080320234727/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2008/0316/cork.html| archivedate= 20 March 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and [[Wexford GAA|Wexford]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=91468|title=Wexford fuming over handling of Cork crisis|accessdate=19 March 2008}}</ref> both lodged unsuccessful appeals against the decision. Wexford's case was taken to the Disputes Resolution Authority but was rejected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=93918|title=Wexford board accuses GAA of breaking rules|accessdate=29 April 2008}}</ref>
===Hurling league controversy=== When the [[National Hurling League 2008]] ended, the Cork and [[Waterford GAA|Waterford]] hurling teams both finished on level points. The CCCC ruled that the teams had to play each other in a [[play-off]] and that scoring difference could not be used to separate the teams. (The play-off was to determine which team entered the semi-final and which entered the quarter final.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=91778|title=Playoff for Cork and Waterford|accessdate=26 March 2008}}</ref>)
However, both [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] and [[Wexford GAA|Wexford]] also finished on level points and, having both played Cork, the CCCC ruled the team's standings at the end of the league could be used and thus scoring difference would apply, thus relegating Wexford.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/Dublin/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=91777|title=Wexford lose out|accessdate=26 March 2008}}</ref> This lead Wexford's chairman to accuse the GAA and the CCCC of "making the rules up as they go along".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/hurling/wexford-chairman-accuses-gaa-of-making-up-rules-as-they-go-along-1327336.html|title=Wexford chairman accuses GAA of 'making up rules as they go along'|accessdate=26 March 2008 | work=Irish Independent|first=Colm|last=Keys|date=26 March 2008}}</ref>

{{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{refimprove|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox sports season | title = 2008 ANZ Championship season | league = [[ANZ Championship]] | sport = [[Netball]] | logo = Anzchampionship.png | pixels = 150px | year = 2008 | duration = 5 April 2008 - 28 July 2008 | no_of_teams = 10 | TV = [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]] (Australia) | season_champs = {{ANZC team|Swifts}} | season_champ_name = Champions | second_place = {{ANZC team|Magic}} | minor_premiers = {{ANZC team|Magic}} | MVP = [[Romelda Aiken]] ([[Queensland Firebirds|Firebirds]])
[[Sonia Mkoloma]] ([[Central Pulse|Pulse]]) | seasonslistnames = Adjacent | nextseason_link = 2009 ANZ Championship season | nextseason_year = 2009 }} The '''2008 ANZ Championship season''' was the inaugural season of the [[ANZ Championship]], a new [[trans-Tasman]] [[netball]] competition replacing [[Australia]]'s [[Commonwealth Bank Trophy]] and [[New Zealand]]'s [[National Bank Cup]]. The 2008 season began on 5 April, with competing franchises playing each other once, and playing each franchise from their home country a second time. Four teams progressed to the finals stage, played over three weeks. The grand final was played on 28 July at [[Acer Arena]] in [[Sydney]], with the [[New South Wales Swifts]] emerging victorious over minor premiers the [[Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic]]. Overall, 6792 goals were scored during the season, averaging 98.44 per match. ==Teams== The inaugural season featured five teams from both Australia and New Zealand. In Australia, one team represented each participating [[States of Australia|state]]. In New Zealand, each team represented one or more [[Regions of New Zealand|regions]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team ! Representative area ! The West Coast Fever were the renamed [[Perth Orioles]] and the Tactix were the renamed [[Canterbury Flames]]. Despite West Coast leading 33–16 prior to the decision, the game was declared a draw, with each team receiving one competition point. The goals scored by each team were included in the competition ladder. 33–16 | [[Central Pulse]] | [[Challenge Stadium]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] |} ===Round 11=== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%; border-collapse:collapse;" width=85% |- style="background:#C1D8FF;" ! width=7%|Date ! width=8%|Time ! width=21%|Home Team ! width=6%|Score ! width=21%|Away Team ! width=22%|Venue |- | Saturday 14 June | 2:30 pm | [[Northern Mystics]] | 47–48 | '''[[Adelaide Thunderbirds]]''' | [[Trusts Stadium]], [[Auckland]] |- | Sunday 15 June | 1:30 pm | '''[[New South Wales Swifts]]''' | 61–60 | [[Queensland Firebirds]] | [[State Sports Centre|Sydney Olympic Park Sports Centre]] |- | Sunday 15 June | 5:30 pm | '''[[Canterbury Tactix]]''' | 50–49 | [[Central Pulse]] | [[Westpac Centre]], [[Christchurch]] |- | Monday 16 June | 7:00 pm | '''[[Southern Steel]]''' | 58–43 | [[West Coast Fever]] | [[Edgar Centre]], [[Dunedin]] |- | Monday 16 June | 7:00 pm | '''[[Melbourne Vixens]]''' | 47–40 | [[Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic]] | [[State Netball and Hockey Centre]], [[Melbourne]] |} ===Round 12=== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%; border-collapse:collapse;" width=85% |- style="background:#C1D8FF;" ! width=7%|Date ! width=8%|Time ! width=21%|Home Team ! width=6%|Score ! width=21%|Away Team ! width=22%|Venue |- | Saturday 21 June | 2:30 pm | [[Central Pulse]] | 41–46 | '''[[Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic]]''' | [[TSB Bank Arena]], [[Wellington]] |- | Saturday 21 June | 12:30 pm | [[West Coast Fever]] | 48–54 | '''[[Melbourne Vixens]]''' | [[Challenge Stadium]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] |- | Sunday 22 June | 1:30 pm | '''[[Queensland Firebirds]]''' | 50–36 | [[Canterbury Tactix]] | [[Brisbane Convention & Exhibition Centre]] |- | Monday 23 June | 7:00 pm | '''[[Northern Mystics]]''' | 47–41 | [[Southern Steel]] | [[North Shore Events Centre]], [[Auckland]] |- | Monday 23 June | 7:00 pm | '''[[New South Wales Swifts]]''' | 51–41 | [[Adelaide Thunderbirds]] | [[State Sports Centre|Sydney Olympic Park Sports Centre]] |} ===Round 13=== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%; border-collapse:collapse;" width=85% |- style="background:#C1D8FF;" ! width=7%|Date ! width=8%|Time ! width=21%|Home Team ! width=6%|Score ! width=21%|Away Team ! width=22%|Venue |- | Saturday 28 June | 2:30 pm | '''[[Northern Mystics]]''' | 42–28 | [[Central Pulse]] | [[North Shore Events Centre]], [[Auckland]] |- | Saturday 28 June | 2:00 pm | '''[[Adelaide Thunderbirds]]''' | 66–47 | [[Queensland Firebirds]] | [[ETSA Park]], [[Adelaide]] |- | Sunday 29 June | 11:30 am | '''[[West Coast Fever]]''' | 50–44 | [[Canterbury Tactix]] | [[Challenge Stadium]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] |- | Monday 30 June | 7:00 pm | '''[[Southern Steel]]''' | 47–43 | [[Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic]] | [[Stadium Southland]], [[Invercargill]] |- | Monday 30 June | 7:00 pm | [[Melbourne Vixens]] | 49–62 | '''[[New South Wales Swifts]]''' | [[Vodafone Arena]], [[Melbourne]] |} ===Round 14=== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%; border-collapse:collapse;" width=85% |- style="background:#C1D8FF;" ! width=7%|Date ! width=8%|Time ! width=21%|Home Team ! width=6%|Score ! width=21%|Away Team ! width=22%|Venue |- | Saturday 5 July | 2:30 pm | '''[[Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic]]''' | 69–44 | [[Canterbury Tactix]] | [[Mystery Creek Events Centre]], [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]] |- | Sunday 6 July | 1:30 pm | '''[[Melbourne Vixens]]''' | 56–47 | [[Northern Mystics]] | [[Vodafone Arena]], [[Melbourne]] |- | Sunday 6 July | 5:30 pm | '''[[Southern Steel]]''' | 54–52 | [[Queensland Firebirds]] | [[Edgar Centre]], [[Dunedin]] |- | Monday 7 July | 7:00 pm | [[Central Pulse]] | 32–44 | '''[[Adelaide Thunderbirds]]''' | [[Pettigrew Green Arena]], [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] |- | Monday 7 July | 6:00 pm | [[West Coast Fever]] | 54–63 | '''[[New South Wales Swifts]]''' | [[Challenge Stadium]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] |} ==Finals== The top four teams from the round-robin stages qualified for the finals series, played over a three-week period. These teams were (in descending order) the Waikato/Bay of Plenty Magic (minor premiers), New South Wales Swifts, Adelaide Thunderbirds and Melbourne Vixens. ---- ===Major semi-final=== {{netballbox | bg = EEEEEE | date = Sunday 13 July | time = 17:30 ([[UTC+12:00|UTC+12]]) | report = http://www.anz-championship.com/news/a/swifts-win-thrilling-major-semi-final--57-56/99 | stats = https://web.archive.org/web/20081014032331/http://anz-championship.com/game.asp?game=213584&comp=4999&orgid=2344 | team1 = {{ANZC team|Magic}} | score1 = 56 | team2 = '''{{ANZC team|Swifts}}''' | score2 = '''57''' | Q1 = 15-'''16''' | Q2 = '''17'''-14 | Q3 = 9-'''17''' | Q4 = '''15'''-10 | H1 = | H2 = | ET = | goals1 = [[Irene van Dyk|van Dyk]] {{nb-goal|29|29}}

revision.comment: /* Safety of abdominal exercises */the work's name is "The New York Times"; publisher=>work in cite using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Abdominal exercises''' are those that affect the [[Abdomen#Muscles|abdominal muscles]] (colloquially known as the stomach muscles or "abs"). ==Effects== Abdominal exercises are useful for building the [[Abdomen#Muscles|abdominal muscles]]. This is useful for improving performance with certain sports, back pain, and for withstanding abdominal impacts (e.g., taking punches). According to a 2011 study, abdominal muscle exercises are known to increase the strength and endurance of the abdominal muscles.{{cite journal |doi=10.1519/JSC.0b013e3181fb4a46 |title=The Effect of Abdominal Exercise on Abdominal Fat |year=2011 |last1=Vispute |first1=Sachin S |last2=Smith |first2=John D |last3=Lecheminant |first3=James D |last4=Hurley |first4=Kimberly S |journal=Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research |volume=25 |issue=9 |pages=2559–64 |pmid=21804427}} It has been highly disputed whether or not abdominal exercises have any reducing effect on abdominal fat. The aforementioned 2011 study found that abdominal exercise does not reduce abdominal fat; to achieve that, a deficit in energy expenditure and caloric intake must be created—abdominal exercises alone are not enough to reduce abdominal fat and the girth of the abdomen. Early results from a 2006 study found that walking exercise (not abdominal exercise specifically) reduced the size of subcutaneous abdominal fat cells; cell size predicts type 2 [[diabetes]] according to a lead author. Moderate exercise reduced cell size by about 18% in 45 obese women over a 20-week period; diet alone did not appear to affect cell size.{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/sj.ijo.0803245 |title=Addition of aerobic exercise to dietary weight loss preferentially reduces abdominal adipocyte size |year=2006 |last1=You |first1=T |last2=Murphy |first2=K M |last3=Lyles |first3=M F |last4=Demons |first4=J L |last5=Lenchik |first5=L |last6=Nicklas |first6=B J |journal=International Journal of Obesity |volume=30 |issue=8 |pages=1211–6 |pmid=16446745 |laysummary=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/08/060807154847.htm |laysource=ScienceDaily |laydate=August 7, 2006}} ==Functions of abdominal muscles== Abdominal muscles have many important functions, including in breathing, coughing, and sneezing, and maintaining posture and speech in a number of species.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0301-0082(98)00046-X |title=Control of abdominal muscles |year=1998 |last1=Iscoe |first1=S |journal=Progress in Neurobiology |volume=56 |issue=4 |pages=433–506 |pmid=9775401}} The anterior abdominal wall is made up of four muscles—the [[rectus abdominis muscle]], the internal and external [[abdominal muscle|obliques]], and the [[transversus abdominis]]."The two internal muscles, the internal oblique and the transverse abdominis, respond more to increases in chemical or volume-related drive than the two external muscles, the rectus abdominis and external oblique; the basis for this differential sensitivity is unknown". ==Core training== {{details|topic=Core|Core (anatomy)}} Not only can a one-sided preference for abdominal muscles (lack of exercise focused on other core muscles) result in creating muscle imbalances, but the effectiveness of exercise is also far from what could be achieved with a balanced workout planning. Core training frequently utilizes balance exercises. These are characterized by an unstable position that requires the use of a wide range of muscles which help balance oscillation of the center of gravity. We can balance both in static positions and while performing dynamic movements.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} The goal of core training is definitely not to develop muscle hypertrophy but to improve functional predispositions of physical activity. This particularly involves improving intra- and intermuscular coordination or synchronization of participating muscles. Involvement of the core means more than just compressing abdominal muscles when in crouching or seated position. The role of the core muscles is to stabilize the spine. Resisting expansion or rotation is as important as the ability to execute movement. ==Types== The abdominal muscles can be worked out by practicing disciplines of general body strength such as [[Pilates]], [[yoga]], [[T'ai chi ch'uan|T'ai chi]], and [[jogging]] among others.{{according to whom|date=May 2014}} There are also specific routines to target each of these muscles. ===Momentaneous activity=== One way to estimate the effectiveness of any abdominal exercise is in measuring the momentaneous{{technical statement|date=May 2014}} activity by [[electromyography]] (EMG), with the activity generally being compared to that of the [[Crunch (exercise)|traditional crunch]]. However, an exercise of lower activity performed during a longer time can give at least as much exercise as a high-activity exercise, with the main difference being that a prolonged duration results more in [[aerobic exercise]] than [[strength training]]. The following tables rank abdominal exercises from highest to lowest in terms of activity as determined by the EMG measures:{{cite journal |year=2001 |first1=Mark |last1=Anders |url=http://www.acefitness.org/getfit/studies/BestWorstAbExercises.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815200229/http://www.acefitness.org/getfit/studies/BestWorstAbExercises.pdf |archivedate=August 15, 2007 |journal=ACE fitnessmatters |title=New Study Puts the Crunch on Ineffective Ab Exercises |pages=9–11}} {| |- | {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Activity in rectus abdominis |- ! exercise ! mean
activity1 |- | Bicycle crunch | align="right" | 248% |- | [[Power tower (exercise)#Captain's chairexercise|Captain's chair]] | align="right" | 212% |- | [[Exercise ball]] | align="right" | 139% |- | Vertical leg crunch | align="right" | 129% |- | Torso track | align="right" | 127% |- | Long arm crunch | align="right" | 119% |- | Reverse crunch | align="right" | 109% |- | Crunch with heel push | align="right" | 107% |- | Ab roller | align="right" | 105% |- | Hover | align="right" | 100% |- | [[Crunch (exercise)|Traditional crunch]] | align="right" | 100% |- | Exercise tubing pull | align="right" | 92% |- | Ab rocker | align="right" | 21% |- |} | {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Activity in obliques |- ! exercise ! mean
activity1 |- | Captain's chair | align="right" | 310% |- | Bicycle crunch | align="right" | 290% |- | Reverse crunch | align="right" | 240% |- | Hover | align="right" | 230% |- | Vertical leg crunch | align="right" | 216% |- | Exercise ball | align="right" | 147% |- | Torso track | align="right" | 145% |- | Crunch with heel push | align="right" | 126% |- | Long arm crunch | align="right" | 126% |- | Ab roller | align="right" | 101% |- | Traditional crunch | align="right" | 100% |- | Exercise tubing pull | align="right" | 77% |- | Ab rocker | align="right" | 74% |- |} |} 1Compared to traditional crunch (100%) ===Bicycle crunch=== The bicycle targets the rectus abdominals and the obliques. Also, the rectus abdominals can be worked out with the basic crunch, the vertical crunch, the reverse crunch, and the full vertical crunch, and when at a low enough body fat percentage (10-12% for males, 15-18% for females) the individual parts of the muscle become visible; many refer to this visible separation as a [[Rectus abdominis muscle|six pack]]. By exercising the internal and external obliques the stomach can be flattened while the [[waist]] line can be reduced.{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-exercise-advice.com/abdominal-muscle-anatomy.html |title=Abdominal Muscle Anatomy |date=|accessdate=2010-07-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100727051108/http://www.abs-exercise-advice.com/abdominal-muscle-anatomy.html| archivedate= 27 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} The long arm crunch, in which arms are straightened behind you, adds a longer lever to the move and emphasizes the upper part of the abs. The plank exercise not only strengthens the abs but also the back and stabilizes the muscles.{{cite web|url=http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm |title=Top 10 Most Effective Ab Exercises|date=|accessdate=2010-07-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100811025658/http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm| archivedate= 11 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===Gadgets=== Abdominal exercises can also be performed with the help of some machines and the [[captain's chair]] is one of the most popular machines used in [[gyms]] and [[health clubs]]. Other machines are the Ab Roller, the Ab Rocket Twister, the Chin-up bar in conjunction with Ab Straps and the Torso Track. The [[exercise ball]] is also a tool that helps strengthen the abs. It may be more effective than the crunches on the [[floor]] because the abs do more work as the legs are not involved in the exercise.{{cite web|url=http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm |title=Top 10 Most Effective Ab Exercises |date=|accessdate=2010-07-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100811025658/http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm| archivedate= 11 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} With respect to the Ab-Slide, the study performed by Bird et al. showed greater muscle activation in the upper rectus abdominis, lower rectus abdominis, and external oblique when compared to the standard abdominal crunch. The Ab-Slide has proven to be an effective tool in strengthening the abdominal muscles from a concentric muscle action perspective. However, this research does not support replacing the traditional crunch exercise with the Ab-Slide gadget due to the lack of proven effectiveness in the eccentric loading of the abdominal muscles and the greater postural control.Michael Bird, Kate M. Fletcher, and Alex J. Koch. Electromyographic Comparison of the Ab-Slide and Crunch Exercises. Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research. 20(2), 436–440, 2006.{{cite web |url=http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm |title=Top 10 Most Effective Ab Exercises |accessdate=2010-07-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100811025658/http://exercise.about.com/od/abs/ss/abexercises_10.htm| archivedate= 11 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Potentially the most effective equipment for abdominal strengthening are those that offer the least stability. Examples include the CoreFitnessRoller, bodyweight suspension training such as TRX and stability balls with or without the Halo. ==Safety of abdominal exercises== Abdominal exercises also put some degree of compressive force on the lumbar spine, putting unwanted stress on the lower back. In addition, exaggerated abdominal exercise can cause respiratory problems.{{cite journal |id={{INIST|18626671}} |doi=10.1152/ajpregu.00409.2006 |title=Increased fatigue resistance of respiratory muscles during exercise after respiratory muscle endurance training |year=2006 |last1=Verges |first1=Samuel |last2=Lenherr |first2=Oliver |last3=Haner |first3=Andrea C. |last4=Schulz |first4=Christian |last5=Spengler |first5=Christina M. |journal=American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology |volume=292 |issue=3 |pages=R1246–53 |pmid=17068160}} A study of twelve exercises concluded that no single [[exercise]] covered all abdominal muscles with high intensity and low compression.{{cite journal | volume=29 | issue=6 | pages=804–810 | year=1997 | author=CT Axler|author2=SM McGill | journal=Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | title=Low back loads over a variety of abdominal exercises: Searching for the safest abdominal challenge | pmid = 9219209 | doi=10.1097/00005768-199706000-00011}} {| border="1" cellpadding="10" cellspacing="0" |- valign="top" | style="background:#bfffbf;" | * High challenge-to-compression ratio ** Crunch with feet anchored ** Crunch with feet free ** Bicycle crunch ** Hanging straight leg raise | style="background:#ffffbf;" | * Low compression, lower challenge ** Crunch with feet anchored ** Crunch with feet free |- valign="top" | style="background:#ffffbf;" | * High challenge, higher compression ** Straight-leg [[Sit-up (exercise)|sit-up]] ** Bent-leg sit-up | style="background:#ffbfbf;" | * Low challenge-to-compression ratio
(''not recommended!'') ** Supine straight-leg raise ** Supine bent-leg raise ** Hanging bent-leg raise ** Static cross-knee crunch |} The benefit of focused training on the "deep core" muscles such as the [[Transversus abdominis muscle|transversus abdominis]] has been disputed, with some experts advocating a more comprehensive training regimen.{{cite news | url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/core-myths/ | title=Is Your Ab Workout Hurting Your Back? | last=Reynolds | first=Gretchen | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=2009-06-17 | accessdate=2009-06-19 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090620142017/http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/core-myths/| archivedate= 20 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==See also== *[[Abdomenizer]] *[[Abdominal fat]] *[[Chin-up bar]] *[[Core (anatomy)]] *[[Crunches]] *[[Pilates]] *[[Roman chair]] *[[Situps]] *[[Spot reduction]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Strength training exercises}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abdominal Exercise}} [[Category:Exercise equipment]] [[Category:Bodyweight exercise]]

{{Refimprove|date= November 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox venue | name = Akita Prefectural Gymnasium | nickname =秋田県立体育館 | logo_image = Akita Prefectural Gymnasium logo.png | logo_caption = | image = Akita prefectural gymnasium.jpg | caption = Akita Prefectural Gymnasium | fullname = | former names = | location = [[Akita, Akita|Akita]], Japan | coordinates = {{coord|39|43|10|N|140|5|37.9|E|source:jawiki_type:landmark_region:JP|display= inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1968 | opened = | renovated = 2012 Flooring and seatings{{cite web |last=Akita Prefectural Gymnasium|first= |url=https://plaza.rakuten.co.jp/akitasogokosya2/diary/201209280000/ |title= 県立体育館　フロア（床）改修工事が終了しました！！|date=28 September 2012 |accessdate=18 October 2017}} | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Hardwood | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = Yoshio Kobayashi and Masatoshi Soh | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Yokohama Giga Spirits|Akita Isuzu Motors]] (1968-1987)
[[Akita Northern Happinets]] (2010-16) | embedded = | website = {{URL|www.akisouko.com/ken_tai/index.html}} | publictransit = }} [[File:Akita prefectural gymnasium 090923.jpg|thumb|300px|Main Arena]] [[File:Akita Prefectural Gymnasium.png|thumb|300px|Satellite view]] {{nihongo|'''Akita Prefectural Gymnasium'''|秋田県立体育館|''Akita Kenritsu Taiikukan''}} is a stadium in [[Akita, Akita|Akita]], [[Akita Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. The gymnasium was built in 1968. Yoshio Kobayashi and Masatoshi Soh were the architects. Masao Sitoh and Arata Ono were the structural engineers. It is {{convert|3|km|mi}} west of the [[Akita Station]]."[http://www.anc-d.u-fukui.ac.jp/~ishikawa/japanese%20structure/akita/1968-steel-JPN-07/Akita%20Prefectural%20Gymnasium.html The detail of "Akita Prefectural Gymnasium":]" [[University of Fukui]], Faculty of Engineering, Department of Architecture and Civil Engineering. Retrieved on 28 September 2012. The gymnasium has two separate facilities. The "large gymnasium" has a floor area of 1736 sq.meters, and a capacity of 6000 spectators. It can be divided into two basketball, two volleyball, two tennis, 10 badminton or 20 table tennis competitions, or can be used for gymnastics, wrestler, boxing, fencing or other activities. The "small gymnasium" has a floor area of 463.1 sq.meters, and can be used for one volleyball, two badminton, two tennis, or other events. Akita Prefectural Gymnasium hosted the 1979 [[World Boxing Association]] World Junior middleweight title match between [[Masashi Kudo]] of Japan against [[Ayub Kalule]] of Uganda on 25 October 1979. ==Entertainment events== *[[Pink Lady (band)|Pink Lady]] 1970's *[[Chage and Aska]] 20-21 October 1993 *[[Kazumasa Oda]] 15 April 2012 *[[Dreams Come True (band)|Dreams Come True]] 19-20 March 2016 ==Sports events== *Kirin World Basketball - [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|University of Kentucky]] vs [[Japan national basketball team|Japan]] 7 July, 1982 *Kirin Cup Basketball - [[Portugal national basketball team|Portugal]] vs [[Japan national basketball team|Japan]] 24 July, 2003 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.akisouko.com/ken_tai/index.html Akita Prefectural Gymnasium] {{ja icon}} {{Akita Northern Happinets venue navbox}} [[Category:Akita Northern Happinets]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Japan]] [[Category:Gyms]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1968]] [[Category:Sports venues in Akita Prefecture]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Akita, Akita]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Japan]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Japan]] {{Japan-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox gymnast |name= Anastasiya Antonovna Kisse |gender= w |image= |image_size= |caption= |fullname= |altname= |nickname= |country= {{flagu|Bulgaria}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1995|7|27|df=y}} |birth_place= [[Odessa]], [[Ukraine]] |hometown= |residence= [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]] |death_date= |death_place= |height= 170 cm |discipline= RG |level= Senior International Elite |natlteam= |club= [[Levski Sofia (sports club)|Levski]] |gym= |collegeteam= |assistcoach= |headcoach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= 2014 |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals= yes }} '''Anastasiya Kisse''' ({{lang-bg|Анастасия Антоновна Кисе}}; {{lang-uk|Анастасія Антонівна Кіссе}}; born {{birth date|1995|7|27|df=yes}}) is a Bulgarian and Ukrainian individual [[rhythmic gymnast]]. She represented her nation at international competitions. She competed at world championships, including at the [[2011 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships]].
She holds both Bulgarian and Ukrainian citizenships.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships athletes - Anastasiya Kisse|url=http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/00000A010100FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF02|publisher=Longinestiming.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref>
== Early life == Anastasiya was born on July 27, 1995 in [[Odessa]], [[Ukraine]]. She was born to the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] politician of [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] origin [[Anton Kisse]] and his wife Galina Kisse.
== Education == Kisse has lived and studied in [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Azerbaijan]] and [[The United Kingdom]]. She has graduated secondary school in [[London]], [[England]] after living there for 3 years. She has studied [[Law]] in Bulgaria for 1 year and currently studies [[Finance]] in [[UNWE]] in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]]. She also has a Bachelor's and master's degree from the [[K. D. Ushynsky South Ukrainian National Pedagogical University]] in [[Odessa]].
She speaks several languages including [[English language|English]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]].
== Career == Kisse starts training at the age of 3 in [[Ukraine]]. Later she moves and continues training in [[Bulgaria]]. She has also lived and trained in [[Azerbaijan]] and with the national team of [[Russia]] in Novogorsk in [[Moscow]]. She was a member of the Junior Olympic team of rhythmic gymstastics of [[Bulgaria]]. Kisse has taken part and won medals in the Junior Olympic Games and many more.
However, Kisse is forced to retire from sports after her last trauma in the back, which doesn't allow her to continue training. She puts an end to her career in 2014.
She is currently working in the [[Russian embassy]] in Sofia, as well as a trainer to an [[Estonian people|Estonian]] gymnast.
== Personal life == Anastasiya's father is the current president of the Association of Bulgarians of Ukraine and the deputy of the [[Verkhovna Rada]] of Ukraine [[Anton Kisse]]. Anastasiya has two older brothers, Gennadiy and Maksim. Gennadiy has graduated [[Law]] in the [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and currently works as an assistant to the [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine]], while Maksim has graduated the [[Odessa National Economics University]] in Ukraine. Anastasiya holds both Ukrainian and Bulgarian citizenship.
Anastasiya is close friends with the Russian [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's rhythmic individual all-around|2016 Olympic All-around silver medalist]] [[Yana Kudryavtseva]] and the [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's rhythmic individual all-around|2016 Olympic All-around Champion]] and [[gold medalist]] [[Margarita Mamun]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== *http://g-ritmica.blogspot.com/2010/09/la-maestria-de-anastasiya-kisse.html * https://database.fig-gymnastics.com/public/gymnasts/biography/9847/true?backUrl=%2Fpublic%2Fresults%2Fdisplay%2F1862%3FidAgeCategory%3D6%26idCategory%3D77%23anchor_2268
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Kozaemon Hisamitsu mounted and armored, but bareheaded, on his galloping steed.jpg|200px|thumb|A Japanese warrior fighting from horseback]] {{Nihongo||馬術|'''Bajutsu'''}} is a [[Japan]]ese form of military [[equestrianism]].
==History== Although its origins are closely related to those of mounted archery (''[[yabusame]]''), bajutsu is considered a distinct and separate martial art, and there are a number of traditional schools, such as the Ogasawara, Otsubo, and Hachijo.<ref>Mass, Jeffrey P.; ''The Origins of Japan's Medieval World: Courtiers, Clerics, Warriors, and Peasants in the Fourteenth Century'' Stanford University Press, 2002. footnote p433</ref> The art originated in the 7th century AD during the reign of [[Emperor Tenji]]<ref>''Kodansha encyclopedia of Japan, Volume 3'' Kodansha, 1983 p229</ref> but was popularised in the 12th century as large-scale mounted warfare became more common.<ref>Deal, william E.; ''Handbook to life in medieval and early modern Japan'' Oxford University Press, 2007, p155</ref> However, the comparative scarcity of horses in Japan meant that bajutsu was always an elite art, restricted to high-ranking [[samurai]].<ref name="Lowry">Lowry, d; ''The Karate Way: Discovering the Spirit of Practice'' Shambhala Publications, 2009 p55</ref> In spite of this, many contemporary historians ignored the numbers of foot-soldiers in battles and referred to the size of armies by the number of horsemen alone.<ref name="Friday">Friday, Karl; ''Samurai, warfare and the state in early medieval Japan'' Psychology Press, 2004 p96-101</ref>
The comparative peace of the [[Tokugawa shogunate|Tokugawa era]] from 1600 onwards led to a decline in the military practice of bajutsu, and it became relegated to a more ceremonial role,<ref>Ratti, O and Westbrook, A; ''Secrets of the samurai: a survey of the martial arts of feudal Japan'' Tuttle Publishing, 1991 p292</ref> indeed, the practice of horsemanship was actively discouraged during the reign of [[Tokugawa Tsunayoshi]].<ref>Murdoch, J; ''A history of Japan: volume 3'', Routledge, 2004, p192</ref> By the beginning of the 20th century there were more than 20 schools of bajutsu<ref>Frédéric, Louis; ''Japan encyclopedia'' Harvard University Press, 2005 p354</ref> and the Japan Bajutsu Federation was formed in Tokyo in 1946 to promote it as a modern sport.<ref>Japan Tsūrisuto Byūrō, ''Japan: the new official guide'' Japan Travel Bureau, 1957 p221</ref>
==Techniques== As well as requiring proficiency in riding and mounted sword-fighting, the art also included teachings on the care and upkeep of horses.<ref>Durbin, W: ''The Fighting Arts of the Samurai: a Warrior's Combat Handbook'' in ''Black Belt Magazine'' March 1990 Vol. 28, No. 3 ISSN 0277-3066</ref> Horses were trained to ignore sudden shocks, and to press forward in the charge, veering off at the last second to allow the rider to kick with his battering-ram-like [[Abumi (Japanese stirrup)|stirrups]].<ref name=Lowry/> These stirrups (''shitanaga abumi'') were designed to enable the rider to stand and shoot easily from the [[Kura (Japanese saddle)|saddle]].<ref name=Friday/> Cavalry charges were made possible by the development of [[Yari|spear]] techniques from horseback in the late 14th century, supplanting the mounted archery styles that had previously dominated.<ref>Turnbull, Stephen; ''War in Japan 1467-1615''Osprey Publishing, 2002 p16</ref> Such charges were used to great effect by the [[Takeda clan]], who introduced the tactic during the mid- to late- sixteenth century,<ref name="Grant2011">{{cite book|author=R. G. Grant|title=Commanders|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sxY4Tz_R4NUC&pg=PA120|accessdate=15 June 2012|date=1 March 2011|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|isbn=978-1-4053-3696-3|pages=120}}</ref> but after the [[Battle of Nagashino]], were used only in conjunction with infantry manouevres.<ref name="Turnbull2002">{{cite book|author=Stephen Turnbull|title=War in Japan 1467-1615|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tYnqTBN19TYC&pg=PA18|accessdate=15 June 2012|date=19 August 2002|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-84176-480-1|pages=18–20}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Commons category|Depictions of samurai on horses}}
[[Category:Japanese martial arts]] [[Category:Equestrian sports]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name=CIG de Malley |nickname=CIG |image=LHC Team - Lausanne Hockey Club vs. HC Viège, 01.04.2010-2.jpg |image_size=250px |location=Chemin du Viaduc 14 1008 Prilly
[[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] |coordinates={{coord|46|31|43.38|N|6|36|0.40|E|region:CH|display=inline,title}} |broke_ground= |opened=1984 | closed = April 2017 | demolished = April 2017 |owner= |operator= |construction_cost= |architect= |tenants= [[HC Lausanne]] (1984-2017)
[[Davis Cup]] ([[Switzerland Davis Cup team|Switzerland]]-[[Belgium Davis Cup team|Belgium]]) ([[2008 Davis Cup|2008]]) |seating_capacity=[[Ice hockey]]: 7,600
[[Tennis]]: 6,237 }} '''Centre intercommunal de glace de Malley''' (abbreviation '''CIG de Malley''' or '''CIGM''') was an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]]. It was primarily used for [[ice hockey]], and was the home arena of the [[HC Lausanne]] from 1984 to 2017. CIG de Malley opened in 1984 and had a capacity of 9,000 people,[http://www.eurohockey.com/arena/1194-patinoire-de-malley.html Patinoire de Malley] although because most of the arena consisted of [[Terrace (stadium)|terraces]] a maximum of 12,000 people could attend the games.[http://www.hockeyarenas.com/lausanneenglish.htm Patinoire Malley]
The arena hosted the [[Suproleague|European champions cup]] final on April 2, 1987, in which [[Olimpia Milano|Tracer Milano]] prevailed over [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] 71-69[http://www.pianetaolimpia.it/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=539&mode=&order=0&thold=0 Olimpia 1966-96... Ovvero la Milano che era sempre in finale raccontata ai vente] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629120341/http://www.pianetaolimpia.it/modules.php?name=News |date=29 June 2007 }}[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c1/C1_87.htm Champions Cup 1986-87] in front of 10,500 spectators. Other important basketball matches hosted at the Malley include the 1994[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c2/C2_94.htm European Cup 1993-94] and 2000 [[Saporta Cup]] finals.[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c2/C2_2000.htm Saporta Cup 1999-2000]
The CIGM hosted the [[1997 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] as well as the 1990 and [[2008 European Men's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]].
It also hosted the Grand Prix of [[skateboarding]] in 1996, 1998, 2000 and 2002.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9BT5RgF1C40 Grand Prix of Skateboarding 2002] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.espacemalley.ch/ Official site] *[http://www.lausannehc.ch/aspage.asp?pid=313916107v8,4,2005x4,40,47x,t Info from lausannehc.ch] *[http://www.daviscup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieID=100010748 Davis Cup (Switzerland-Belgium) 2008] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Euroleague|FIBA European Champions Cup]]

[[Budapest]] | after=[[Flanders Expo]]
